answers.answer: Very very doubtful this is related to cancer.  More likely a little infection of a hair follicle or a milk duct.  Your college should have a clinic.  Try there.  good luck

question: Yesterday I found a small painful bump on my areola that hurts to touch. It’s smaller than a pea, but I can feel a bit hardness underneath the surface. The bump is a bit raised and red on the surface and almost has a small indentation? I’m 18 and in college, and even though it’s only been a day I’m kind of freaking out about it. I did some research and keep thinking I have a subareolar breast abcess?  I’m really worried and don’t know what to do—I don’t have an official adult doctor yet, and pretty much still go to a mainstream pediatrician. It feels better today than it did yesterday, but I’m panicking over the things I’ve read about these things sometimes being rare forms of cancer.I have no history of breast cancer or anything in the family, and nothing like this has ever happened to me. I have no nipple piercings and don’t have diabetes which websites said were risk factors for breast abscesses in woman who aren’t breastfeeding…what could have caused this? Is it safe for me to wait a few days and see if it goes away on its own or do I need to rush to a doctor? And if so how do I do that if I don’t have a doctor yet? I would like to avoid bringing this up to my parents if it’s a trivial problem that can go away on its own.I’m really scared, any advice would be helpful. Thanks
title: I found a small painful bump on my areola that hurts to touch?
